title: Why a Good Beaujolais Vintage Means Great Value for Us
text:
A GREAT VINTAGE in Burgundy inspires legions of buyers to pursue the very best wines, often regardless of very high prices. A great Beaujolais year? I’d bet most oenophiles couldn’t name one.

In fact, the years 2015-2018 were all very good Beaujolais years. “We have been lucky to have four good vintages in a row,” noted Gregory Barbet, managing director of Domaine de la Pirolette in the Beaujolais village of Saint-Amour.

So why haven’t more wine drinkers taken note? The top Beaujolais crus have plenty in common with their Burgundy peers; Beaujolais is, after all, a subregion of Burgundy. The fact that these very good wines are usually much cheaper than comparable ones from other regions in Burgundy means they’re often great value—and often underestimated as well.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS Have you tried Beaujolais? And no, we don’t mean Nouveau! Join the conversation below.

Mr. Barbet’s family is one of the oldest and best-known names in Beaujolais. They co-own two other important estates, too: Domaine des Billards in Saint-Amour and Château de Fleurie in Fleurie.

Saint-Amour and Fleurie are among the 10 Beaujolais crus—the appellations that produce serious wines that have nothing to do with the faddish product of barely fermented juice called Beaujolais Nouveau. These range widely in size and soil type as well as styles of wine produced. Saint-Amour wines are often flamboyantly fruity in their youth, while Fleurie wines have lovely floral aromas (the village’s name means “flowery”). The wines from Morgon are rich and substantial; those from Moulin-à-Vent, more structured and tannic.

In an effort to drive Beaujolais Nouveau from the world stage (or at least a bit closer to the curtains) and further emphasize the importance of its crus, Inter Beaujolais, the wine trade council, recently changed “Beaujolais Nouveau Day” to “Beaujolais Day.” Instead of celebrating the day that Beaujolais Nouveau wines arrive in the market—traditionally the third Thursday of November—now all Beaujolais wines will be heralded.

Though any Beaujolais is also Burgundian, oenophiles commonly reserve the latter term for certain long-lived Beaujolais crus like Moulin-à-Vent and Morgon. It implies complexity and structure rarely associated with Gamay, the red grape of Beaujolais.

Complex is certainly the word for wines from Jean Foillard, whose rich, multilayered 2017 Jean Foillard Cuvée Corcelette Morgon ($38) could command twice the price if it was produced in a different Burgundy zone. The friends I gathered recently to taste Beaujolais with me loved the Foillard—but when I told them the price, they balked. “That’s not what Beaujolais costs,” said one. To her, Beaujolais should be “always under $20 a bottle.”

“ ‘It’s a vintage the famously exacting Jean-Paul Brun declared “perfect.”’ ”

Brian Lynch, the Berkeley, Calif.-based national sales director of Kermit Lynch Wine Merchant, observed that it’s “interesting” to him that consumers only recognize prestige in certain regions. “You can buy the best wines from the Beaujolais for under $50,” he wrote in an email. “In how many regions does $50 allow you to drink wines from the best crus and from the best producers?”

Joe Salamone, wine buyer for Crush Wines & Spirits in New York, said that while many wine drinkers are like my friends, he’s also finding more willing to spend money on a good cru Beaujolais. He posited that a rise in prices has been a boon to their reputation. “Sometimes you have to be somewhat expensive to convince people that you are worth paying for,” he noted in an email.

According to Mr. Lynch, prices of Beaujolais crus imported by Kermit Lynch Wine Merchant have increased by 1-4% in each of the past four vintages, “consistent with all the quality producers in Beaujolais.”

One superstar Beaujolais estate in the Kermit Lynch portfolio, Château Thivin, turns out Beaujolais-Villages as well as several wines from the Brouilly and Côte de Brouilly crus. I purchased three: the 2017 Château Thivin Côte de Brouilly Cuvée Godefroy ($35), the 2017 Château Thivin Côte de Brouilly La Chapelle ($30) and the 2018 Château Thivin Côte de Brouilly ($24). Marked by complex aromas of red fruit, spice and earth, the Godefroy was particularly opulent and lush. The La Chapelle, initially a bit tight, bloomed in the glass. The 2018 Côte de Brouilly was beautifully balanced, substantial yet polished.

Later I discovered the first two are not officially available in the States. According to Anthony Lynch, son of importer Kermit Lynch, both wines are made from small parcels of very old vines and sold only in France (apart from a few bottles I found at Crush Wine & Spirits). The 2018 Côte de Brouilly, however, is widely distributed stateside.

I had quite a few very good 2017 Beaujolais crus, including a delightful 2017 Daniel Bouland Chiroubles Chatenay ($24), all snappy red cherry fruit, and the 2017 Domaine des Billards Saint-Amour, bright and juicy and, at $18 a bottle, priced at a point my friends would happily pay; the marvelously plump and fruity 2017 Château de Fleurie Fleurie went for the same price. The 2017 Jean-Paul Brun Domaine des Terres Dorées Fleurie ($22) was more darkly fruited and more structured.

I found a few 2018 wines as well, though bottles from this vintage are just arriving in the market and are currently less plentiful than 2017 Beaujolais. There were two 2018 wines of note from Jean-Louis Dutraive, one of the most highly regarded Beaujolais producers, who makes wines in both Brouilly and Fleurie. The two I tasted were both from Fleurie: the 2018 Domaine de la Grand’Cour Cuvée Vieilles Vignes Fleurie ($42) and the 2018 Domaine de la Grand’Cour “Clos de la Grand’Cour” Fleurie ($38). Both were very well made. The Vieilles Vignes bottling was more complex, richer and more substantial; it could use a bit more time in the bottle. The Clos de la Grand’Cour was fresh and vivid with red fruit aromas that practically burst from the glass.

Perhaps when all the 2018 cru Beaujolais hit store shelves in the next several weeks, wine drinkers will finally take note. It’s a vintage the famously exacting Jean-Paul Brun declared “perfect.” And if oenophiles have to pay a few dollars above what they think the wines “should” cost, take my word, these wines are worth even more.

OENOFILE / BEAUTIFUL, QUAFFABLE, NOTABLY AFFORDABLE BEAUJOLAIS

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

1. 2017 Jean-Paul Brun Domaine des Terres Dorées Fleurie $22

Jean-Paul Brun, a master of Gamay, the grape of Beaujolais, makes a range of wines from various appellations. This one, from Fleurie, is ripe and medium bodied with soft tannins—a pleasurable drink.

2. 2017 Jean Foillard Cuvée Corcelette Morgon $38

This is a lush and complex wine, “Burgundian” in every sense of the word, from the great Jean Foillard. Marked by dark fruit and aromas of earth and spice, it’s compulsively drinkable.

3. 2018 Jean-Louis Dutraive Domaine de la Grand’Cour “Clos de la Grand’Cour” Fleuri $38

From the outstanding 2018 vintage, a lithe and lissome wine with the lovely floral aromas typical of Fleurie, snappy red cherry fruit and a lively acidity, this wine is a pure joy.

4. 2017 Château de Fleurie Fleurie $18

Lush and aromatically beguiling with plenty of plump red fruit, this Fleurie from the historic Château de Fleurie delivers uncomplicated pleasure at a price far lower than it should reasonably be expected to go for.

5. 2018 Château Thivin Côte de Brouilly$24

Silken-textured yet substantial with a firm mineral edge, this bottling of the polished Château Thivin Côte de Brouilly presents a prime example of the superb balance exhibited by best Beaujolais of the 2018 vintage.

description: Recent years have been very good indeed, and yet wine drinkers often underestimate the best Beaujolais. Is it because the prices seem too good to be true?
